title: Is Uncanny Valley a real phobia for most people? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think it's not phobia, just an uneasy feeling that, “something's not right with that person”. So the context is, of course, computer-animated human. We know it's not real. But as it gets more and more human-like, subconsciously we start to measure what we see against our concept of how a human should look like/act. And at this point in time, computer-animated humans still have some imperfections. And that causes us to think, “something's not right with that person” rather than “wow this animation is so lifelike”. And that's why animation powerhouses like Disney, Pixar, and Dreamworks purposefully designed their characters with “cartoony” qualities: To stay away from the uncanny valley.

Most people have not been exposed to situations that might have an Uncanny Valley effect. Where it does happen, it’s more an impression that “something doesn’t smell right here” … it seems a bit weird. For now, the Uncanny Valley idea is not a term about a widespread and psychological phenomenon, it is a somewhat subtle idea about aesthetics and feeling, circulated among technologists and especially, designers. They have different sensitivities than the general public.
